Appendix 1:  Adapted Abbey Pain and Agitation Assessment Guidance Appendix 2: Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose

The purpose is to provide a set of practical skills to assess pain in the older patient. In addition this guideline will also include assessment of those who cannot reliably communicate and their pain relief requirements, including patients who have any degree of cognitive impairment. Included will be the different tools the assessor can use to determine the patients pain. This is the first step to methodically and effectively managing the patients' pain. The guideline will also provide a guide to the management and prescribing for pain in the older patient and for those who have cognitive impairment.
Background

Pain is under-recognised and under treated in older people. National UK statistics have indicated that pain or discomfort was reported by about half of those over 65 years old, and 56% of men and 65% of women aged 75 years of age. Samples taken from older people in care homes showed 45-83% of patients had reported at least one current pain problem.

Assessment should include pain intensity, character and the area affected. Verbal, pictorial and numerical rating scales can be used. Scales should be presented to the patient in their own language, in clear large font or format. If the patient has a communication aid, for instance glasses or a hearing aid, these should be in situ to optimise assessment and allay anxiety. For patients with no cognitive impairment, and no issues relating to the above the general MEHT scale may be used (the 0 – 3 scale). 0 is equal to no pain, 1 equal to mild pain, 2 equal to moderate pain, and 3 equal to severe pain. Pain should always be assessed on movement; for example, leaning forward or deep breathing/coughing.

The term ‘cognitive impairment' for this guideline's purpose encompasses ‘any patient who is unable to communicate their needs reliably'. This does not just include patients with dementia: other examples where the Abbey Scale can be used include patients with advanced Parkinson's Disease or Multiple Sclerosis, post-stroke and/or mute: however this is not an exhaustive list. The Abbey Pain Scale is an appropriate tool and should be used for initial and subsequent assessments and evaluation of treatment to ensure continuity. Where cognitive impairment changes, e.g. a patient admitted with a urinary tract infection which caused confusion, and where the confusion has now resolved, the patient assessment tool can be changed to the standard MEHT 0-3 scale and documented in the clinical notes.
Scope
The guideline is to be used by all health care professionals, for the assessment and management of pain in older patients, and patients who are unable to communicate their needs reliably.
Pain Assessment

Standard patient assessment includes the use the MEHT 0 – 3 Scale and is carried out by direct enquiry to the patient. This is used where there is no evidence of cognitive impairment, i.e. the patient is able to communicate their needs clearly and reliably. Pain is assessed on movement. (Refer to ‘Management of severe pain – general guidelines and essential information'; register number 06007)
The assessor should recognise that older people may be reluctant to acknowledge and report painand may use a wide range of alternative descriptors, other than “pain” itself, to describe their pain.

Attempts to locate pain can be made by asking the patients to point to the area on their body. Pain maps can be used to assist in identifying both the location and the extent of pain. Careful physical examination should be undertaken to identify any treatable causes. Treatable causes are common in older people, e.g. Arthritis, muscle stiffness etc. However, pain can exist in the absence of treatable cause. Seek medical advice if there are concerns about cause of pain.

Where cognitive impairment is identified or suspected the Abbey Pain Scale should be used. This is based on observational changes that may be associated with pain; this may include behavioural changes, changes in body language, vocalisation, and facial expression. The Abbey scoring system is sometimes referred to as the pain and agitation scale. Agitation can be a sign of a patient in pain. The assessor will observe the patient and score them in each category. The sum of the scores is calculated. The maximum score is 18. A score of 0 to 2 refers to no pain, 3 to 7 refers to mild pain, 8 to  refers to moderate pain, and a score of 14+ refers to severe pain. See Abbey Pain Scale in Table 1 in appendices. This has been modified to reduce subjectivity of the scorer.

For patients with learning disabilities, please refer the patient to the Learning Disabilities Hospital Liaison Nurse for help in understanding how to assess and help this vulnerable group. For patients with severe & profound learning disabilities, the DisDAT assessment tool and Hospital Passport can be used to identify pain and distress for people who are non-verbal or have extremely limited communication skills. The care provider should provide these tools at point of patient admission. Where the patient is admitted without these resources, then the assessment tools are freely available and can be downloaded from the intranet under the Learning Disability clinical pages. These should then be passed on to the carer who has a responsibility to complete the documentation. A copy should be taken and held in patient medical/nursing notes. Refer the patient to the Learning Disabilities Hospital Liaison Nurse for further help.

Review the patient's medical history, physically exam the area, and take note of laboratory and diagnostic tests in order to understand sequence of events that may be contributing to pain. Refer to the patients' doctor with these details.

Assess present pain, including intensity, character, frequency, pattern, location, duration, and precipitating and relieving factors if possible. Ask relatives / carers for relevant and reliable information about the patient, where the patient is unable to. Assess changes in behaviours as an indicator of pain, e.g. increased agitation and confusion can indicate the presence of pain. Assess pain history, including prior injuries, illnesses, and surgeries; pain experiences; and pain interference with daily activities, for example carrying out pressure area care, washing the patient, carrying out dressing changes.

Review medications, including current and previously used prescription drugs, over-the-counter drugs, and complementary therapies (including home remedies). Determine which pain control methods have previously been effective for the patient. Assess if previous analgesics have caused side-effects, e.g. Tramadol often causes / or adds to patient confusion. Ensure that analgesics prescribed for the patient prior to admission are carried on whilst they are an in-patient, unless they have been discontinued for a clinical reason.
Assess history of drug or alcohol abuse.  (Refer to Acute pain management for patients with a history of substance misuse;
register number 06005)

4.9.1  Assess pain regularly and frequently, but at least every 4 hours. This maybe recorded on the patients ‘Care round' documentation if not accessible through Vital PAC. Re-assess the patients pain score 1 hour after giving analgesia to evaluate effectiveness. If symptoms / signs of pain persist, assume pain is unrelieved and treat accordingly. Re-assessment is vital as the patient will not be able to tell you if the analgesia has worked; therefore we will not be able to differentiate between agitation and pain. Agitation unrelated to pain needs to be treated differently not with analgesia.
Management of Pain
Develop a written pain treatment plan upon admission to the hospital, or prior to surgery or treatments. Include relevant pain history and co-existing painful conditions and medication.

Assess pain regularly and frequently to facilitate appropriate treatment at least every 4 hours. Monitor treatment effects within one hour of analgesia administration. Evaluate patient for pain relief and side effects of treatment. Document patient's response to treatment effects by means of variance in care in the care round document. Document treatment regime in the patients' care plan to facilitate consistent implementation.

Consider there may be a neuropathic element to the patient's pain, for example post-herpetic neuralgia, stroke pain, sciatica, diabetic neuropathy, etc. (Refer to ‘Neuropathic pain – general guidelines and essential information'; register number 11063)
Educate patient, their families, and other clinicians to use analgesic medications prophylactically prior to and after painful procedures. Anticipate and aggressively
treat for pain before, during, and after painful diagnostic and / or therapeutic
treatments, e.g. dressing changes, etc. Administer opioid analgesics  minutes
prior to these activities. (Refer to ‘Management of procedural pain'; register number 06001)

Educate patients to take medication for pain on a regular basis and to avoid allowing pain to escalate, ensuring that informed consent is implied having explained the drug and its potential benefits and side effects. The patient has a right to refuse analgesia. Consider and utilise non-drug strategies appropriate to the patient's needs and preferences.
Educate patients, families, and other clinicians to use non-pharmacological strategies to manage pain, such as relaxation, massage, and the use of heat and cold.

Administer pain drugs on a regular basis to maintain therapeutic levels. Use as needed (prn) medications for breakthrough pain. If prn usage is high, the patient's regular analgesia may need increasing. Monitor patient for side effects.

Choose the appropriate type, dose and route of analgesic. Use the oral route when it can be tolerated. Select the analgesic based on thorough medical history, comorbidities, other medications, and history of drug reactions. Older adults are at increased risk for adverse drug reactions due to age- and disease-related changes in pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. Monitor medication effects closely to avoid over / under medication, and to detect adverse effects. Assess hepatic and renal functioning. See Adapted pain and agitation assessment guidance document in Appendix

Note non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), should be used with caution in older adults: this may include reducing the dose. Monitor for renal function, gastrointestinal (GI) irritation and/or bleeding and consider giving with a proton pump inhibitor to reduce gastric irritation. Also monitor for bleeding, nephrotoxicity,
and delirium. Limit the period of administration of regular NSAIDs to 5 days before clinical review.
Staff and Training
Approved guidelines are accessible from the staff intranet under clinical guidelines.
All clinical staff are to read the Abbey Pain Management PowerPoint Presentation available on the intranet under training films.
In addition, the clinical guideline will be disseminated to the ward through Pain Link nurses within their ward setting.
The new guideline will be introduced to anaesthetic staff through anaesthetic meetings.
Pharmacy are involved and made aware of the new guideline.

Training and education is provided by the IPMS, both formally and informally for all clinical staff. The IPMS is available for advice and consultation via the pager system, and through the PAS referral system.
Corporate services will ensure that the guideline is uploaded to the intranet and notified to staff via Focus.
Infection Control

The Trust policy for prevention of cross infection is to be adhered to for all patient contact procedures. The infection prevention practice within MEHT is for all staff to have strict hand hygiene before and after patient contact. Any equipment must be cleaned between patients unless it is a single use item which will be disposed of appropriately as per the Waste Management Policy.
Use Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT) when administering injections.
Non-Compliance with this Guideline
Failure to provide regular assessment and effective pain management is a breach of patient rights, and has clinical and non-clinical repercussions:
Patient satisfaction and well-being is compromised
Accountability and professional responsibility is breached
Clinical risk is increased, due to multi-systemic influence of pain
Delayed discharge from hospital decreases Trust efficiency and increases risk of hospital-inquired infection
A Datix form should be completed and submitted to the Risk Management Department for non-compliance with this guideline.

Incidence of clinical risk or patient complaints resulting from non-compliance with this guideline are to be recorded via the central risk events database and PALS (Patient Advisory Liaison Service) if involved.
Potential issues and updates will be brought to the attention of the MEHT Dementia Steering group, and information will be cascaded to staff where required.
Audit and Monitoring
The use of this guideline will be monitored by review of any reported incidents and annual audit.
Clinical meetings for Link nurses are held three times a year. Potential audit discussion and problems can be evaluated in this meeting.

The IPMS manager and lead consultant will liaise at corporate level to put strategies in place to address issues that may arise. This can also be brought to the attention of the Dementia Steering group which meet every fortnight.
References

AGS Panel on Persistent pain in older persons (2002). The management of persistent pain in older persons. Journal of the American Geriatrics Society Vol 50, No. (6 Supplement) ppS205-224.
Kaye, A.D, MD, Baluch, A., Scott, J. (2010.) Pain management in the elderly population: a review. Ochsner Journal 10(3): pp179–187.,

Document on every shift that the Abbey Pain scale is being used. Tick the Abbey pain scale box in care document.

Document pain score in care round document. Where additional analgesia (PRN) is required document what was given in the care document indicating a variance (V) in care. Re-assessment post analgesia is
essential otherwise we cannot know what effect the analgesia has had. The patient will not be able to tell us.
When pain is re-assessed document the pain score in the care document. An Abbey pain score here is all that is required, do not write ‘given with good effect' for example.

Care plans-please sign and date to indicate care plan has commenced, document the ‘goal' required. Circle or add nursing actions required. Do not initial and date the ‘change section' on the care plan unless reviewed and changes are made to the care plan.

data.text: If the patient's pain is not controlled the patient may require additional analgesia, or a different type of analgesia, e.g. an anti-neuropathic analgesic. Also, consider this may be agitation and not pain related – reassessment is key. Giving opiates to a patient who is agitated and not in pain can cause respiratory depression.
